data.text: Lagarde: While all options are on the table, the PEPP and TLTROs have proven their effectiveness in the current environment and can be dynamically adjusted to react to how the pandemic evolves. They are likely to remain the main tools for adjusting our monetary policy 5/6

Lagarde: The best contribution monetary policy can make is to ensure favourable financing conditions for the whole economy. This is why the Governing Council announced last month that we will recalibrate our instruments, as appropriate, to respond to the unfolding situation 4/6

Lagarde: A continued, powerful and targeted policy response is vital to protect the economy, at least until the health emergency passes and vaccination is well advanced. The right policy mix is essential 3/6

Lagarde: This unusual recession has posed exceptionally high risks and required an exceptional policy response. What has defined this response is the policy mix. Macroeconomic, supervisory and regulatory authorities have dovetailed and made each other’s efforts more powerful 2/6

(THREAD) The coronavirus has produced a highly unusual recession and is likely to give rise to an unsteady recovery, says President Christine Lagarde in her opening remarks at the #ECBForum on Central Banking https://t.co/783Wy8WRHs 1/6
LIVE: ECB President Christine Lagarde opens the 2020 #ECBForum on Central Banking. https://t.co/ycXJl8ovgI

A digital euro would be banknotes in digital form, but it would not replace cash, says ECB economist Ulrich Bindseil on #TheECBPodcast. What would the benefits of a digital euro be, and how could it affect the way we pay? Find out more with @MichaelSteen https://t.co/yBeazuTXZ2 https://t.co/U44CxrBGar

What would you like to ask Andrew Bailey, Christine @Lagarde and Jerome Powell? Post your question using #ECBForum by Thursday, 12 November at 12:00 CET – it may be selected for discussion at the policy panel.

Follow live on Twitter and on our website tomorrow from 17:45 CET. https://t.co/9PH8cE5vHN

Coming up from 14:00 CET: Day 1 of the 2020 #ECBForum on Central Banking. Discussions will focus on the economic impact of the coronavirus and the ECB’s strategy review. Check out the programme https://t.co/P93rcohD3D https://t.co/63A6WQg60H
Euro area securities issues statistics (Sept 2020) https://t.co/gDm8ks6P1M
POLL: Join the conversation at this week’s #ECBForum on central banks in a shifting world. Aside from the coronavirus, what do you think is the single greatest challenge currently facing the world?

3, 2, 1… The countdown to this year’s young economists’ competition has started! Check our website to meet the finalists, who will join the #ECBForum on 11-12 November to share their research findings. https://t.co/msXQdfSLGx https://t.co/ZX2m1BZav9
Working paper: Reversal interest rate and macroprudential policy https://t.co/pFqKNb1y4V

Occasional paper: Liquidity in resolution - Estimating possible liquidity gaps for specific banks in resolution and in a systemic crisis 
https://t.co/3fyghR6d23
Pandemic-induced HICP measurement and interpretation challenges have receded recently
Consumption shifts leave a gap between HICP and price changes of goods actually purchased by consumers

Economic Bulletin Box: Consumption patterns and inflation measurement issues during the COVID-19 pandemic
https://t.co/7xyJ2kPUUz

The speed of economic recovery is highly uncertain and depends on how the pandemic and related containment efforts evolve. But it is clear that fiscal and monetary policy measures play a pivotal role in protecting the economy from a persistent shock and excessive damage [4/4]

Estimates of potential output are uncertain and will change as the situation evolves and as the pandemic’s economic impact becomes clearer. Yet, it is already evident that potential output is likely down less than GDP – indicating a negative output gap [2/4]

The coronavirus pandemic has lowered potential output in the euro area. Labour, capital, and total factor productivity were all affected. Read more in the #EconomicBulletin [1/4] 

https://t.co/ybH2zYS6rj https://t.co/OgZH351Gyj

Financial market integration in the euro area is back at pre-coronavirus levels for most indicators, high-frequency data show. The recovery of market integration is fragile and relies on fiscal, monetary and prudential support. Read our #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/gqNihgquSq https://t.co/mxZA2aMEsv

Tune in at 15:00 CET to watch ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria look back at the first six years of European banking supervision in a panel discussion at the online #PIIEFinancialStatements event with @Nicolas_Veron https://t.co/oYdpN7L51V https://t.co/4iaTjnnD0L
Economic Bulletin:  In debt markets, pension funds invest mostly long term and in government bonds
Economic Bulletin: Pension funds invest in a geographically broad area, but obtain capital locally
Economic Bulletin: Euro area pension funds mainly invest in investment fund shares and debt securities
Economic Bulletin: Euro area pension fund assets have almost doubled over the past two decades

Economic Bulletin Article: New pension fund statistics
https://t.co/881RsVfFs6

https://t.co/SH9QT3qytN

What is a digital euro? What would its benefits be and how would it affect the way we make payments? When could it be ready? Tune into the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with Ulrich Bindseil and host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/yBeazuTXZ2 https://t.co/5gRtTQG7js
ECB publishes consolidated banking data for end-June 2020 https://t.co/apS5kUQfsX

Tune in at 11:40 CET to watch ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos discuss the euro area's economic outlook and challenges arising from the second wave of the coronavirus pandemic at the online Thessaloniki Summit https://t.co/Qb1x5aEZVo https://t.co/REF54Jj4SY

This year’s #ECBForum on Central Banking takes place next week, on 11 and 12 November. Discussions will focus on the economic impact of the coronavirus and the ECB’s strategy review. The Forum will be webcast live – check out the programme https://t.co/P93rcohD3D https://t.co/g9K5E6Zu3q

FR: https://t.co/eRJyu1EgVv
NL: https://t.co/1gnHSbxQAp

Na de eerste fase van de coronacrisis is een belangrijke vraag hoe het nu verdergaat, zegt Andrea Enria, hoofd van ECB-Bankentoezicht tegen De Tijd. Het kredietrisico is erg hoog en de kwaliteit van bankactiva zal verslechteren. Maar wanneer en hoe sterk is niet te voorspellen. https://t.co/Lbk5FqKSnC

La première vague de la crise du coronavirus passée, il importe d’envisager l’avenir, déclare Andrea Enria à l’Écho. Le risque de crédit est très élevé et la qualité des actifs des banques va se détériorer. Mais nous ne pouvons pas dire quand ni dans quelle mesure. https://t.co/WJcrN0uxp7

Enria: Banks loaded with bad loans would not be able to lend and support the economy. A European asset management company would help avoid this, and strong conditionality and common criteria would ensure it would not be used to support unhealthy banks https://t.co/iXRN90KgIY 3/3

Enria: A second wave of the pandemic coupled with a sluggish recovery could significantly worsen banks’ asset quality and capital positions. Banks must be proactive in managing customers and take early action to avoid a huge rise in bad loans 2/3

(THREAD) After the initial phase of the coronavirus crisis it is important to ask what happens next, says ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria to l’Echo/De Tijd. Credit risk is very high and banks’ asset quality will deteriorate. But we cannot foresee when, and how deeply 1/3 https://t.co/hy21IGkHEL

Thank you again to all the civil society organisations that participated in our #ECBListens event on 21 October. We have just published the summary report of the event on our website https://t.co/kt7UqiV0Ua https://t.co/o6caznywPM

The deteriorating growth outlook requires further monetary policy support to safeguard favourable financial conditions, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. While conditions are changing, our response will remain proportionate to the risk https://t.co/2E7UON6iHV https://t.co/J3wzlqlLGm
Working paper: Interest rate-growth differentials on government debt - An empirical investigation for the euro area https://t.co/rLF3gRQC8y
Results of the September 2020 survey on credit terms and conditions in euro-denominated securities financing and over-the-counter derivatives markets (SESFOD) https://t.co/4DUvM7ziMj

Condividi con noi la tua opinione! Abbiamo aperto due consultazioni pubbliche sull’euro digitale e su un nuovo modello di sorveglianza relativo a strumenti, schemi e funzionalità di pagamento elettronico. Maggiori informazioni qui https://t.co/cbioWMqpSc

Le stablecoin segnalano la necessità di cambiamento, ma possono comportare seri rischi per la stabilità finanziaria, la sovranità monetaria, la competitività e l’indipendenza tecnologica, afferma il Membro del Comitato esecutivo Fabio Panetta @payvolution https://t.co/ECLNfquSmL https://t.co/lwAcJyW5u9

Panetta: We are also seeking your views on a #digitaleuro. It would complement cash, not replace it, providing citizens with costless access to a simple, risk-free and trusted digital form of central bank money https://t.co/RiwOCers68 5/5

Panetta: We have just launched a public consultation on our new oversight framework for electronic payment instruments, schemes and arrangements. It is inspired by the principle of “same business, same risks, same rules”. Have your say! https://t.co/iZPSyF2bqR 4/5

Panetta: To stimulate safe and efficient EU payments that are fit for global competition, we are implementing a comprehensive policy based on complementary elements:
a retail payments strategy
a possible digital euro 
an innovative payment oversight framework
3/5

Panetta: Central banks, financial regulators, and data protection and competition authorities need to respond to the transformation of the payments landscape by promoting a competitive and innovative market and completing the regulatory and oversight framework 2/5

(THREAD) Global stablecoins are an expression of the need for change, but they can pose serious risks to financial stability, monetary sovereignty, competition, data protection and technological autonomy, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta https://t.co/yEzHyMyWVg 1/5 https://t.co/EBRZmUfxus

When the ECB first reacted to the coronavirus crisis, the main concern was to stabilise financial markets, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Today, the economic and financial situation differs and we will take this into account in the recalibration of our instruments. https://t.co/gq4jygf9Fl https://t.co/gKU05TXYva
Interview @Isabel_Schnabel with Handelsblatt https://t.co/xc3jxnjryf (EN) https://t.co/sYr8VI5MT2 (DE)

Enria: Looking ahead, a European network of asset management companies could speed up restoring asset quality. There is also urgent need to tackle banks’ low profitability – mergers can be a solution, possibly spurred on by digitalisation https://t.co/0P4mZFBkrX 3/3

Enria: Banks must now brace for weakening loan quality that will result from the crisis. They must distinguish viable customers from non-viable, while also adjusting capital projections to more pessimistic scenarios 2/3

(THREAD) Banks’ strengthened capital positions allowed us to release capital buffers in response to the coronavirus crisis, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. This helped prevent a sharp tightening of credit standards and supported financial stability 1/3 https://t.co/de5CWGh5Jb

The ECB has acted forcefully and well within its mandate in response to the coronavirus pandemic, says Executive Board member Yves Mersch. He states that, as the crisis evolves and subsides, the ECB will reconsider its tools and supervisory practices 
https://t.co/TvUW4aSh3x https://t.co/crR0qUKyoL
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Sept 2020) https://t.co/n7lK3i2dUi

The crisis is likely to lead to seriously impaired balance sheets and asset quality, says Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul. Surviving the crisis will require decisive management action, suitable board members and effective credit risk management https://t.co/UCFH6KYUXt https://t.co/p7fCtE5yUE
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Gunnar Beck, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/CodB4kMP4P
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Markus Ferber, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/hmbwmKBn4N
Letter from the ECB President to Ms Eleonora Evi, Ms Rosa D’Amato, Mr Ignazio Corrao and Mr Piernicola Pedicini, MEPs, on monetary policy https://t.co/HKOiQkAnL5
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/dBNO9WNq5B

How usable are regulatory capital buffers, and what factors may prevent banks from using them in the crisis? What is the importance of countercyclical buffers for releasing capital? Read this and more in the Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/6V8p4vHWVL https://t.co/GCbgEb7Th9

With high uncertainty clouding the macroeconomic picture, it is not surprising that the outlook for banks is also still unclear, says Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick. Banks should give supervisors a fair picture of asset quality and capital https://t.co/Rv7NWwsG8T https://t.co/gnnuvZwAcN
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine Lagarde explains the latest monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/9Fu0PlDMUw
How are our Executive Board members chosen? Find out who proposes the candidates and how they are selected https://t.co/T3nSvI3pkT

The Governing Council has no objection to the proposed appointment of @FrankElderson as a member of the Executive Board. If appointed, Mr Elderson will succeed Yves Mersch. Next steps: 
➡️ Opinion of the @Europarl_EN
➡️ Appointment by the European Council
https://t.co/nLWiRm0eKg https://t.co/gx07blR1eN
The winner of the competition will be announced at the #ECBForum on 12 November. Stay tuned! https://t.co/PGirmFKcXJ

Inspiring and fascinating is how this year’s #youngeconomists described their meeting with ECB Executive Board members Philip R. Lane and @Isabel_Schnabel, who encouraged them to further pursue their research by highlighting the importance of academic studies for policy-making. https://t.co/S6568WxO5b

Right now: ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in a hearing at the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee. 
Watch the discussion https://t.co/0LhD131axP
Read the introductory statement https://t.co/9d865YUq15 https://t.co/iTmKmFo6ye

Watch ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria exchange views with the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee the impact of the coronavirus crisis on banks, bank’s preparedness for Brexit, climate-related risks to banks, and completing the banking union https://t.co/0LhD12Jz9f https://t.co/dXUQaRFwQl

Enria: We also need an integrated response, where at least funding and pricing are anchored at the European level. A European asset management company, or a network of national asset management companies, would be an effective solution 3/3

Enria: This time we need to tackle bad loans more quickly and use the opportunity for a deeper restructuring of the banking sector. Asset management companies can help banks to clean up their balance sheets and improve the viability of their business models 2/3

(THREAD) Asset management companies could be the tool that allows us to avoid repeating past mistakes in dealing with non-performing loans, writes Andrea Enria in an op-ed https://t.co/tUlryPtZjn 1/3 https://t.co/3CvCmRK2Kw
We asked 143 banks in the euro area about changes in their lending behaviour and loan demand during the third quarter of 2020. Find out the result https://t.co/4wWeay1yiK
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in September? How do they compare with August figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/gz7TQndETa https://t.co/5w80JJtYBU

Price stability matters for your everyday life, whether you are saving, borrowing, spending or investing. That’s why we want your input before making decisions on our future strategy. Have your say via the #ECBListens Portal before it closes on 31 October https://t.co/HmgNlLYpK9 https://t.co/5FtqXC4Nix

The capital relief measures introduced since the start of the crisis have so far not been fully reflected in the target capital ratios banks have announced. Pressure from credit and equity investors can be a key explaining factor. Read the full article https://t.co/6V8p4vHWVL https://t.co/CssjhBCgxd

Capital buffers are intended to be used in a crisis as shock absorbers, but certain factors can prevent banks from drawing them down. What does this imply for future macroprudential policy? Read the full article https://t.co/4a1qyHJJX9 https://t.co/r7xoSKCQRu

Here they are! This year’s ten young economists’ competition finalists are from seven different countries, and are researching challenges facing our economy. Watch their videos on our website to learn more https://t.co/J2sBrSHO7C https://t.co/8ygrge0VjO

Banks have been resilient in the coronavirus crisis and the digital transformation is well underway, says Supervisory Board member @PenaHakkarainen at an @EBFeu conference. But as threats from cybercrime increase, banks must improve their cybersecurity https://t.co/SjSg77pWTP https://t.co/IA0OwYIFth

EDP general government deficit/debt, Autumn notification (Eurostat). Reference period: 2019
https://t.co/68kbdr8C4f

The ECB’s virtual Monetary Policy Conference discussed the review of the monetary policy strategy and the reaction of different policy areas to the economic challenges induced by the pandemic. Watch the keynote lectures on our website 
https://t.co/QBvI3lqHPy

Panetta: A digital euro would make digital central bank money accessible to everyone. It would provide access to a simple, costless, risk-free and trusted digital means of payment that is accepted throughout the euro area. More about a digital euro https://t.co/RiwOCers68 6/6

Panetta: It is critical that issuers and service providers of significant stablecoins are regulated and supervised at European level. At the root of our oversight activity lies the principle of “same business – same risks – same requirements” https://t.co/CBcQujXwyY 5/6

Panetta: Our aim is that payments meet consumer demand while preserving European sovereignty. We will work towards: 
continued provision of cash, 
pan-European solutions for retail payments, 
a new oversight framework for electronic payments, 
and a digital euro
4/6

Panetta: On the one hand, the acceleration towards digital payments is adding to the diversity of payment methods. On the other hand, there is a risk of excessive concentration and insufficient competition in each market segment 3/6

Panetta: Radical innovation and new players are shaping the market and have the potential to bring more choice, efficiency and inclusion to payments. But an uncontrolled transition could lead to risks for consumers and financial stability 2/6

(THREAD) Central banks are adapting their policies to ensure that payments remain efficient and inclusive, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. Authorities must be ready to respond to the ongoing transformation of European payments https://t.co/CBcQujXwyY 1/6 https://t.co/s9FE7ETyrt
